questions.question_text: Which QoS queuing method discards or marks packets that exceed the desired bit rate of traffic flow?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
This one made me read the entire QOS chapter again (netacad module 3 chapter 9), because of the way the question is asked...

"discards or (re)marks packets" -> definitely policing

But it never buffers. 

So for me based on what you see in ccna it's defnitely not a Queuing method/algo, it's a congestion avoidance tool.

comments.content:
CBWFQ can be configured to mark or drop specific traffic but it isn't on be default. https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios/12_0t/12_0t5/feature/guide/cbwfq.html#:~:text=CBWFQ%20allows%20you%20to%20specify,case%20with%20flow%2Dbased%20WFQ.

LLQ doesn't seem to mark anything, IE record it, so the answer is probably CBWFQ even though you have to configure it?
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/qos/configuration/guide/12_2sr/qos_12_2sr_book/llq_for_ipsec.html

discussion.content: This question might be confusing at least it was for me. Question states "which queuing method" and gives answers such as CBWFQ and LLQ which are queuing tools. Policing on the other hand is considered its own QoS.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
some websites said the answer is LLQ. I think the answer should be policing, but 'which queueing method' made me confused jeez

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

D. Marking

The other options, shaping, policing, and classification, do not directly change the ToS field in the IPv4 packet header.
the answer is correct

comments.content:
Yes it is correct. 
Marking is a method that you use to modify the QoS fields of the incoming and outgoing packets. The QoS
fields that you can mark are IPprecedence and differentiated services code point (DSCP) in Layer 3. The QoS
group is a label local to the system to which you can assign intermediate marking values. You can use the
QoS group label to determine the egress scheduling.
DSCP is the equivalent to ToS but it interprets the field differently.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/nx-os/nexus9000/101x/configuration/qos/cisco-nexus-9000-nx-os-quality-of-service-configuration-guide-101x/m-configuring-marking.pdf
https://linuxreviews.org/Type_of_Service_(ToS)_and_DSCP_Values

discussion.content:
It seems like this is correct? I don't see how this is CCNA level...
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/quality-of-service-qos/qos-packet-marking/10103-dscpvalues.html#anc22

choices.C: Relies on the well-known UDO port 69 for data transfer
choices.D: Uses two separate connections for control and data traffic

questions.question_text: What is the function of FTP?
How does TFTP operate in a network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Seems correct as a,b,d makes no sense.

Block Number : The Block Number field on Data Packets starts with one and then increase sequentially by one for each new packets. This type of numbering allows TFTP applications to identify between new DATA packets and duplicates.
https://www.omnisecu.com/tcpip/tftp-data-packet.php#:~:text=Block%20Number%20%3A%20The%20Block%20Number,from%200%20to%20512%20bytes.

CORRECT !
ADVICE DON'T TAKE THE EXAM IF YOU'RE NOT READY OR PREPARED VERY VERY VERY WELL THAT WILL MAKE YOU LOSE 300 DOLLARS

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
uses block numbers to identify and mitigate data transfer errors

Selected Answer: C
The answers A, B and D are features of FTP not TFPT so answer C is the only correct one.

choices.D: Requires two separate connections for control and data traffic
choices.C: Uses block numbers to identify and mitigate data-transfer errors
choices.B: Relies on the well-known TCP port 20 to transmit data

choices.C: Remark traffic as it traverses R1 and trust all markings at the access layer.
choices.A: Trust the IP phone markings on SW1 and mark traffic entering SW2 at SW2
choices.B: As traffic traverses MLS1 remark the traffic, but trust all markings at the access layer
choices.D: As traffic enters from the access layer on SW1 and SW2, trust all traffic markings.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
The IP phone will mark the voice traffic at the phone, so trust this on SW1.
The PC traffic will need to be marked at SW2.
Marking is occurring as close to the edge as possible without client intervention.
Option ‘A’ correctly identifies this.
I am pretty sure all/most of the traffic marking should be done on the lower layers ie access layer. Answer A seems correct.
